content.title: STATUS AND TRENDS
content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

This lesson delves into statistics on the global energy gap, focusing on access to fundamental energy needs: electricity, clean cooking, and heating and cooling. Each part examines the unique hurdles and advancements within these critical areas, highlighting both the progress achieved and the remaining gaps on the path toward universal, sustainable energy access.

concepts.title: access to clean cooking
concepts.body: Access to clean cooking refers to the availability and use of safe, efficient, and environmentally friendly cooking methods and fuels, which reduce health risks and environmental impact compared to traditional cooking practices.

concepts.title: heating and cooling fuels and technologies
concepts.body: Heating and cooling fuels and technologies refer to the various energy sources (like natural gas, electricity, and renewable options) and systems (such as furnaces, heat pumps, and air conditioners) used to regulate indoor temperatures for comfort and efficiency.

content.intro: M2: Energy Access and Inclusive Energy Services | Chapter 2 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Building blocks of sustainable energy

content.text: Part 1 Overview

As explained earlier in this module, electricity access is a critical driver of sustainable development, yet vast disparities persist worldwide. This section explores recent data on global electricity access, revealing both significant progress and ongoing challenges across different regions, urban and rural areas, and specific vulnerable contexts.

According to The Energy Progress Report 2024, a staggering 685 million individuals still lacks access to electricity, with a significant portion, residing in sub-Saharan Africa. Current projections estimate that by 2030, around 660 million people could still be without electricity access, largely due to the challenges of serving remote, low-income communities (IEA et al., 2024). However, these figures may underestimate the true scale of the issue, as energy access metrics often count a household as “electrified” based on a single point of connection, even if electricity was only available for a day at some point in time. This can mask the reality of unreliable, insufficient, or unusable electricity services, especially in fragile or informal settings. Select any country in the interactive chart below to see its level of energy access as of 2021
Urban vs. rural trends in access to electricity

Progress has been made in recent decades, with global electricity access rising from 78% in 2000 to 91% in 2022. However, a different picture emerges when breaking down electricity access along global energy access gap - i.e., by country type, urban vs. rural areas, and considering additional layers, as described to follow.
Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and regions impacted by fragility, conflict, and violence (FCV)

Least Developed Countries (LDCs) and regions impacted by fragility, conflict, and violence (FCV) face additional challenges. Between 2020 and 2022, energy access gains slowed in these areas, leaving approximately 486 million people in LDCs and over 429 million in FCV countries without electricity.
Access to electricity in community services and public institutions

Nearly 1 billion people in low- and lower-middle-income countries rely on health-care facilities with unreliable or no electricity. In South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa, 12% and 15% of health-care facilities lack electricity access, with only half of hospitals in sub-Saharan Africa having reliable power, especially in rural areas. (WHO, 2023) In addition, globally, 77.4% of primary schools and 90.6% of upper secondary schools have electricity access. In sub-Saharan Africa, only 32% of primary and 52.2% of upper secondary schools are electrified, while in least developed countries, access rates are 38% and 60.4%, respectively (Our World in Data, 2022).
Technologies status and trends

Decentralized renewable energy offers a viable solution to electrify hard-to-reach rural areas, home to many of the remaining unconnected populations. In 2022, the IEA reported that solar home and lighting systems brought electricity to 2.5 million households, with off-grid solar solutions serving an estimated 490 million people. Of these, 158 million had solar access meeting international quality standards. Additionally, 47 million people were connected to 19,000 mini-grids, with hydropower and solar accounting for one-third of these installations (IEA et al., 2024).

These variations in electricity access highlight the vast differences in how countries and institutions define and measure access, which is an important distinction shaping both data and policy responses. In some contexts, electricity access is defined simply as a physical connection to the grid, regardless of quality or reliability. In others, it includes minimum service levels such as the ability to power basic appliances, number of hours of supply per day, or affordability. For example, India considers a village electrified if at least 10% of households and public institutions have access to electricity (PRS India., 2017) while the World Bank’s Multi-Tier Framework (MTF) assesses access based on capacity, duration, reliability, quality, affordability, legality, and safety (ESMAP, 2015). These contrasting definitions can lead to major discrepancies in reporting and in understanding the real impact of electrification efforts. To ensure meaningful progress toward universal energy access, strategies must be tailored to regional and national contexts, taking into account not just connection rates but also the quality, reliability, and inclusiveness of energy services. This is particularly critical in underserved rural areas and informal settlements, where basic energy needs often remain unmet despite being counted as “electrified.”

content.title: Part 2: Access to Clean Cooking Fuels and Technology

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Access to clean cooking facilities remains a critical yet often overlooked component of global energy access. Clean cooking solutions present a vital opportunity to improve public health, promote gender equality, and foster economic empowerment, particularly in low-income and conflict-prone settings. This section examines recent data on global clean cooking access, highlighting both significant progress and persistent challenges across regions, urban and rural areas, and vulnerable contexts.

Clean cooking facilities enable families to prepare meals safely, contributing to better maternal and child well-being. Household air pollution from cooking caused an estimated 3.2 million deaths in 2020 (WHO, 2023), disproportionately affecting women and children, who make up 60% of these cases (Clean Cooking Alliance, 2023). In low-access African countries, over 53% of infant mortality is linked to pollution-related illnesses (Showbande, 2020). The burden of collecting biomass falls largely on women and girls—400 million of whom are biomass producers in the global energy system. In Sub-Saharan Africa, they spend five hours daily on cooking tasks, limiting education and work opportunities and costing the global economy $800 billion annually (UNDP SEH, 2024). Clean cooking solutions could alleviate this "time poverty." In conflict zones, lack of clean cooking options also heightens exposure to gender-based violence, such as the 42% of such cases in Chad occurring during firewood collection (Clean Cooking Alliance, n.d.).

In 2022, 74% of the global population had access to clean cooking, up from 64% in 2015, yet about 2.1 billion still rely on polluting fuels like charcoal, coal, dung, kerosene, and wood. If current trends persist, 79% will have clean cooking access by 2030, leaving nearly 1.8 billion exposed to the adverse effects of polluting cooking fuels. (IEA et al., 2024). The access deficit has consistently declined in Eastern, Southeastern, Central, and Southern Asia, driven by gains in the most populous low- and middle-income countries like India, China, Indonesia, Nigeria, and Pakistan. However, Sub-Saharan Africa lags behind, with 79% of its population and 33% in Central and Southern Asia still relying on polluting fuels. If these trends continue, Sub-Saharan Africa’s access deficit could exceed 1 billion by 2030. Immediate and focused interventions are necessary to tackle this growing challenge.
Urban vs. Rural Trends in Clean Cooking Fuels and Technologies

Significant disparities in access to clean cooking fuels and technologies persist on a global scale, with urban areas generally enjoying greater access than rural counterparts, although the gap is gradually closing. Click on any part of the interactive chart below to see specific data per year on rural vs. urban access to clean cooking fuels:

The urban-rural gap across regions has been narrowing in all regions. However, in Sub-Saharan Africa this gap is rising sharply, with only 7 percent of rural households have access to clean cooking, compared to 40 percent in urban areas. In Latin America and the Caribbean, 35% of the rural population lacks access to clean cooking, roughly twice the urban rate.
Fuel Mix Evolution: From unprocessed biomass to gaseous fuels

A notable evolution in the fuel mix is underway, marked by a transition from unprocessed biomass to gaseous fuels (LPG, natural gas, and biogas) This transition started around 2010 with the rapid expansion of LPG programs in countries such as India, Indonesia, and Peru. Despite this evolution, rural areas still heavily rely on biomass, serving as the primary cooking fuel for 45% of people (1.4 billion) in 2022, surpassing all other fuel types. While the use of unprocessed biomass may be on the decline in both urban and rural areas, a persistent reliance on charcoal is observed, especially in some urban areas of Sub-Saharan Africa. In 2022, charcoal was the primary cooking fuel for 30% of the population, totalling 146 million individuals.

content.title: Case Study: Sierra Leone

content.text: Case Study RBA: Energy Efficient Production and Utilization of Charcoal through Innovative Technologies and Private Sector Involvement in Sierra Leone
The problem

During the 1980s and 1990s, charcoal emerged as a minority urban fuel, gradually surpassing firewood and becoming the preferred fuelwood for the majority of urban residents. However, the traditional charcoal and cookstoves sub-sector in Sierra Leone has long suffered from informality, lack of regulation, and fragmentation, with inefficient production systems heavily reliant on non-renewable sources and inconsistent policy statements.
Project objectives and funding

Addressing these challenges, the Global Environment Facility-financed, UNDP-supported Project on Energy Efficient Production and Utilization of Charcoal through Innovative Technologies and Private Sector Involvement in Sierra Leone aims to generate economic, social, and environmental benefits. The project encourages sustainable charcoal production from renewable sources and the promotion of improved cookstoves to mitigate deforestation, enhance public health, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Specifically, the initiative aims to support alternatives to traditional charcoal such as sustainably produced charcoal using improved kilns and alternative biomass fuels like sawdust briquettes and agricultural residues, to reduce deforestation, improve energy efficiency, and lower greenhouse gas emissions.
Project components

The project operates through three main components. The first component emphasizes the establishment of robust policy and regulatory frameworks, enhancing institutional capacity, and formulating effective policies, laws, and regulations related to more efficient charcoal and improved cookstove production.
Public-private approach

The project strives to catalyze public-private initiatives, fostering partnerships along the value chain of charcoal production and utilization. Through the development of incentives, including carbon finance, microfinance, rebates, and loan guarantee schemes, the project aims to scale up sustainable charcoal and improved cookstove businesses. Additionally, the implementation of locally produced industrial stoves for income-generating enterprises and efficient kilns for charcoal production contributes to the project's goals.
Project impact

The project envisions a shift towards improved, more efficient production and utilization of charcoal and cookstoves as common practices in Sierra Leone. This involves gender-sensitive capacity development, promotional schemes emphasizing the social, economic, and environmental benefits of sustainably sourced charcoal and improved cookstoves, and public awareness campaigns to sensitize key value chain actors.
Summary

This project seeks to transform the charcoal and cookstoves sub-sector in Sierra Leone by aligning production practices with sustainability principles, fostering partnerships, and promoting efficient technologies. Through comprehensive policy frameworks, public-private initiatives, and targeted interventions, the project aspires to make certified charcoal and improved cookstoves commonplace, bringing about positive changes in economic, social, and environmental aspects of the country. Sources: · UNDP Sierra Leone (n.d.)Energy Efficient Production and Utilization of Charcoal Through Innovative Technologies · UNDP, GEF (n.d.) UNDP Project Document. content.title: Part 3: Access to Heating and Cooling Fuels and Technologies

content.text: Part 3 Overview

As climate change exacerbates extreme weather conditions, the need for effective heating and cooling solutions becomes increasingly urgent, particularly for vulnerable populations in both hot and cold climates. This section explores the complexities surrounding access to heating and cooling services, highlighting their impacts and consumption trends, while also presenting the challenges associated with measuring and tracking this access. Heating and cooling technologies are integral to access to energy because they are essential for ensuring thermal comfort, health, and productivity, especially in regions facing temperature extremes. Ensuring equitable access to these technologies is thus a key component of inclusive energy access.

While estimates vary, depending on methodological differences, data quality, and assumptions about how humans respond to changes in temperature, the numbers are not small — they range from 1.7 to 5 million (Our World in Data, 2024). Nearly 9.5% of death globally are attributed to sub-optimal temperatures. Are you surprised?
Do you know how many people die from sub-optimal temperatures?

Access to heating and cooling must be understood as a core development variable because of its direct implications for health, education, and productivity (Davis et al, 2021). For example regarding health, air conditioning decreases heat-related mortality by 80% (Shapiro et al, 2016), aggravating health inequalities for those who have no access. Moreover, several studies have connected heat with slower learning, having long-term implications on educational and career outcomes (Zivin, et al, 2020). Heating and cooling play a significant role in both the environment and climate change, accounting for nearly half of global final energy consumption. As the largest source of energy end use, it is responsible for over 40% of global energy-related carbon dioxide emissions. Furthermore, despite a decrease in the share of fossil fuels in heat generation from 91% in 2010 to 75% in 2021, most heat generation still relies on fossil fuels (coal, oil, and natural gas) and unsustainable biomass. Therefore, electrification is essential for achieving universal energy access in unserved regions and for decarbonizing heating and cooling to ensure sustainability (IRENA, 2023).

As heatwaves intensify, the demand for air conditioning is likely to rise, increasing household energy expenditures and potentially pushing millions in hot climates into fuel poverty (UNICEF, n.d.) With global temperatures continuing to rise, the need for cooling solutions will escalate, particularly as living standards improve in developing countries. Global cooling demand is projected to grow by 45% by 2050 compared to 2016 levels (IRENA, 2023). Projections indicate that by 2050, at least 80% of the world’s wealthiest households will have air conditioning, while only 2% to 23% of the poorest households will have access. While regions like North America are over-equipped, only 15% of the 3.5 billion people living in hot climates currently have air conditioning (PreventionWeb, 2023). This disparity highlights the growing inequalities in access to cooling solutions, which are at risk of deepening further.
Complexities in Tracking Heating and Cooling Access

Unlike other energy access indicators, tracking the availability and affordability of heating and cooling solutions is particularly complex due to the wide array of technologies and fuels involved, as well as the varied climatic needs across regions. Heating and cooling solutions span a spectrum of technologies, ranging from traditional methods such as open fires and stoves, to modern appliances. The use of different fuels further complicates the landscape, with regions relying on biomass, fossil fuels, or electricity based on local availability and economic factors. The multifaceted nature of these technologies and fuels makes it challenging to develop a uniform metric for assessing global access. The diverse climatic conditions across regions add another layer of complexity. While some areas require robust heating solutions for colder seasons, others face challenges related to excessive heat, necessitating effective cooling technologies. The dynamic nature of climate-related energy needs emphasizes the importance of region-specific strategies to ensure that populations can access suitable heating and cooling solutions. Specific business and financing models are needed to address heating and cooling access, which will be developed in Chapter 3 in this module, and in module 4 for the financing mechanisms.

Energy efficiency also plays a vital role in ensuring adequate heating and cooling. The quality of housing significantly impacts the effectiveness of these solutions. Well-insulated homes with energy-efficient designs can reduce the demand for excessive heating or cooling, benefiting both energy efficiency and occupant well-being. In contrast, inadequate housing conditions typically lead to higher energy consumption and costs to maintain comfortable temperatures. Since adequate housing is a key component of SDG Indicator 11.1 (Proportion of urban population living in slums, informal settlements, or inadequate housing), monitoring this indicator can help narrow the access gap in heating and cooling technologies. By promoting adequate housing that prioritizes thermal efficiency, policymakers can indirectly improve access to heating and cooling solutions.
Example: Chilling Prospects Initiative

The Sustainable Energy for All (SEforALL) "Chilling Prospects" initiative offers a comprehensive assessment of cooling access risks across 77 countries with a focus on vulnerable populations. The data shows that 1.12 billion people are considered at high risk due to a lack of access to cooling. This includes 306.1 million rural poor lacking electricity access, and 815.0 million urban poor facing challenges with housing quality and intermittent electricity supply. The analysis considers various factors of vulnerability, tracking progress annually with the best available data. It strategically categorizes populations into high, medium, and low-risk groups based on their access to cooling for thermal comfort, food and agricultural produce, and medical products.

The initiative also introduces a gender-specific analysis, acknowledging the differentiated impacts on women. The gender-disaggregated data reveals that women constitute approximately 53% of this population, possibly indicating a higher vulnerability among women compared to men due to intersecting disparities. The recent reduction in the number of people at high risk within the assessment countries, from 1.14 billion to 1.12 billion, signals progress. India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Yemen (prior to the recent civil war) have witnessed substantial reductions in their rural poor populations at high risk, driven by efforts to expand electricity access and reduce poverty. However, the number of urban poor at high risk increased slightly, emphasizing the ongoing challenges associated with rapid urbanization. Expand each of the titles below to see more statistics according to risk level.
High risk

India, China, and Nigeria are home to the largest number of people at high risk, collectively accounting for over 570 million individuals. Fast-growing economies like Bangladesh, Brazil, Indonesia, and Pakistan each have over 30 million people at high risk. The gender disparity persists, with an estimated 414 million women at high risk in the top 10 countries combined (see Figure below). In Africa and Asia, the proportion of the population at high risk remains alarming. For instance, in ten African countries, over 50% of the population faces high risk.
Medium risk

Chilling Prospects identifies 2.90 billion lower-middle-income people at medium risk, representing an increasingly affluent class ready to purchase cooling solutions. This segment faces challenges in selecting sustainable and affordable options, potentially leading to inefficient technologies and increased energy consumption. The number of people at medium risk increased by approximately 11 million between 2022 and 2023, primarily in South Asia, Nigeria, and Yemen.
Low risk

Around 958.7 million individuals within the middle-income population are at low risk. This means the population might typically own air conditioners and refrigerators . This group, living on USD 10.01 to USD 20 per day, exhibits a positive trend in access. The number of people at low risk increased by approximately 56.8 million from 2022 to 2023, showcasing a return to growth after a decline during the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The "Chilling Prospects" initiative presents a snapshot of the global access gap to cooling technologies. While progress has been made in reducing the number of people at high risk, major challenges persist, especially in rapidly urbanizing regions and with regards to the unique vulnerabilities faced by women. Addressing these challenges requires a holistic approach that combines efforts to improve electricity access, housing quality, and the affordability of efficient cooling solutions. The data underscores the importance of tailored interventions to ensure sustainable and equitable access to cooling technologies worldwide. The dynamic nature of climate-related energy needs emphasizes the need for region-specific strategies to ensure that populations can access suitable heating and cooling solutions.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Global electricity access has improved to 91% in 2022, yet 658 million people—mostly in sub-Saharan Africa—remain without access. With rural areas at 85% electrification versus 98% in urban areas, targeted strategies are essential to close this gap.

Clean cooking access is vital for health and gender equity, yet 2.1 billion people still rely on polluting fuels. The urban-rural divide remains severe, especially in sub-Saharan Africa, where only 7% of rural households have clean cooking access compared to 40% in urban areas, requiring urgent interventions.

Climate change is driving a projected 45% increase in cooling demand by 2050, but access is concentrated among wealthier households. With only 2% to 23% of the poorest households expected to have air conditioning, 1.12 billion people are at high risk, including 53% women, who face greater vulnerability.
